docs.lead_paragraph: Just six months after arriving here from a Somalian refugee camp, Ahmed Guled's family has eased into the American mainstream. His children attend the Pilgrim Elementary School. They spend afternoons with Power Ranger reruns. The baby girl toddles around in a Gap T-shirt and denim mini-skirt. Mr. Guled himself holds dear the all-American dream that his children will go to college and prosper in the United States. But he also clings to an ancient tradition that is customary in parts of Africa -- and that became a Federal crime this year.

headline.main: Tug of Taboos: African Genital Rite vs. U.S. Law

docs.abstract: Caseworkers and Federal health officials say stopping practice of female genital cutting among small, but growing, population of African refugees and immigrants in US will entail more than passage of Federal law, and will mean finding way of changing minds of parents who cling to ancient tradition; many refugees have vowed to continue practice, despite passage of Federal law criminalizing it; say they will take daughters back to homelands when necessary; regard female genital cutting as responsibility required by Muslim faith; Centers for Disease Control estimates more than 150,000 women and girls of African origin or ancestry in US may be at risk of having rite performed, or have already been cut; practice is common in 28 countries that span Africa's midsection, but varies widely in prevalance and severity; some ethnic groups do not follow custom at all, while others adhere to it almost without exception; Ahmed Guled, Somali refugee who plans to have rite performed on daughters, comments; photos (L)
